column3: And he shook so, as Tom and Jasper marched him back, escorted by the body guard of the parson and the little doctor, that the two boys put their hands under his arms to help him along.

column2: Well--well--well! ejaculated Mr. King, as he saw this array.
column3: Well-well-well! ejaculated mr King, as he saw this array.

column2: Polly gathered Phronsie's other hand in hers, while she clung closer than ever to Grandpapa.
column3: Polly gathered Phronsie's other hand in hers, while she clung closer than ever to Grandpapa.

column2: Here's your pocket-book, said Tom, handing the article over; "he hasn't spent much."
column3: Here's your pocket book, said Tom, handing the article over; "he hasn't spent much."

column2: Don't, Tom, said Jasper, "joke about it."
column3: Don't, Tom, said Jasper, "joke about it."

column2: Can't help it, said Tom.
column3: Can't help it, said Tom.

column2: Well, now, shall we turn him over to the _sergents de ville?_
column3: Well, now, shall we turn him over to the underscore sergents de ville?underscore

column2: Turn him over? repeated Mr. King.
column3: Turn him over? repeated mr King.

column2: I should say so, he added drily, "and give him the best recommendation for a long term, too.
column3: I should say so, he added drily, "and give him the best recommendation for a long term, too.

column2: What else is there to do, pray tell?"
column3: What else is there to do, pray tell?"

column2: Grandpapa, suddenly cried Phronsie, who hadn't taken her eyes from the man's face, "what are you going to do--where is he going?"
column3: Grandpapa, suddenly cried Phronsie, who hadn't taken her eyes from the man's face, "what are you going to do-where is he going?"

column2: We are going to hand him over to the police, child, answered old Mr. King, harshly.
column3: We are going to hand him over to the police, child, answered old mr King, harshly.

column2: And as soon as possible, too.
column3: And as soon as possible, too.

column2: Grandpapa, perhaps he's got some little children at home; ask him, Grandpapa, do.
column3: Grandpapa, perhaps he's got some little children at home; ask him, Grandpapa, do.

column2: No, no, Phronsie, said Mr. King, hastily.
column3: No, no, Phronsie, said mr King, hastily.

column2: Say no more, child; you don't understand.	Say no more, child; you don't understand.
column3: true

column2: We must call the _sergents de ville."_
column3: We must call the underscore sergents de ville."underscore

column2: At the words _sergents de ville_ the man shivered from head to foot, and wrenched his hands free from the boys' grasp to tear open his poor coat, and show a bare breast, covered with little, apparently, but the skin drawn over the bones.
column3: At the words underscore sergents de ville underscore the man shivered from head to foot, and wrenched his hands free from the boys' grasp to tear open his poor coat, and show a bare breast, covered with little, apparently, but the skin drawn over the bones.

column2: He didn't attempt to say anything.
column3: He didn't attempt to say anything.

column2: Oh, my goodness! exclaimed old Mr. King, starting backward and putting up his hands to his face to shut out the sight.
column3: Oh, my goodness! exclaimed old mr King, starting backward and putting up his hands to his face to shut out the sight.

column2: Cover it up, man--bless me--no need to ask him a question.	Cover it up, man-bless me-no need to ask him a question.
column3: true

column2: Why, the fellow is starving."
column3: Why, the fellow is starving."

column2: His little children--four of them--his wife--all starving--hadn't a bit to eat since, he could scarcely say when, it seemed so very long ago since he had eaten last--it all came out in a torrent of words that choked him, and like the true Frenchman that he was, he gestured in a way that told the story with his face and his fingers, as well as with his tongue.
column3: His little children-four of them-his wife-all starving-hadn't a bit to eat since, he could scarcely say when, it seemed so very long ago since he had eaten last-it all came out in a torrent of words that choked him, and like the true Frenchman that he was, he gestured in a way that told the story with his face and his fingers, as well as with his tongue.

column2: A _sergent de ville_ strolled by and looked curiously at the group, but as Mr. King met his eye coolly, and the party seemed intelligent and well able to take care of themselves, it wasn't necessary to tender his services--if they were talking to a worthless vagabond.
column3: A underscore sergent de ville underscore strolled by and looked curiously at the group, but as mr King met his eye coolly, and the party seemed intelligent and well able to take care of themselves, it wasn't necessary to tender his services-if they were talking to a worthless vagabond.

column2: Hum--hum--very bad case; very bad case, indeed! Mr. King was exploding at intervals, while the torrent was rushing on in execrable French as far as accent went.
column3: Hum-hum-very bad case; very bad case, indeed! mr King was exploding at intervals, while the torrent was rushing on in execrable French as far as accent went.

column2: No one else of the spellbound group could have spoken if there had been occasion for a word.
column3: No one else of the spellbound group could have spoken if there had been occasion for a word.

column2: Then he pulled out the pocket-book again, and taking out several franc notes of a good size, he pressed them between the man's dirty fingers.
column3: Then he pulled out the pocket book again, and taking out several franc notes of a good size, he pressed them between the man's dirty fingers.

column2: Go and get something to eat, was all he said, "and take care of the children."
column3: Go and get something to eat, was all he said, "and take care of the children."
